instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PPVCCIO_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCIO_S0_CPU? PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is a power rail responsible for powering the part of the CPU responsible for communicating with other portions of the machine prior to PPVCORE_S0_CPU being present and must be present before vcore, PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is present when the machine is in an on, RUNNING state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
Got mbp 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> touchbar with water damage. There was damage near lcd area and short on <CHIP>U7220</CHIP>. Changed it and now machine seems to start ( 20V 1,5-2,5Amps). No shit on lcd connector and FPC: 


I checked and see that <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is 0V so it's not enabling backlight , right? 


This signal is generated by <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> checked and it's not generating 0V on <RESISTOR>R9827</RESISTOR>. 


The problem is that it doesnt start even with external monitor. I dont know what this machines do when you connect external monitor and boot them. 


Also it's strange that CPU is getting just warm and GPU stays cold. 


Any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
P.S. SOme additional details: 

Seems that machine is not getting in S0: 

Once it's "on" i can listen battery charging sound when reconect charger. also touchbar is off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
All previous message is nothing. 


I was checking about S0 and see that:


<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - is shorted to ground. Same thing happens with <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>.

P.S: <SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is ok and <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is ok too. 


Dead CPU? 

???????Can fans sping if the cpu is dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - is shorted to ground. Same thing happens with <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>."
I'll be not so sure.
Probably very low values as normal; compare with similar board.

However, overvoltage via <CHIP>U7220</CHIP> is a good reason to have a dead CPU now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
I dont have known good logic board just donor one and resistance to ground is 300Ohms, with one i am repairing is 0,5V so i think it's shorted. What if i inject 1V there?  Anyway if it can be only dead cpu there is nothing to loose. 


Anyway it's first time i see that logic board with dead cpu is starting fans, getting 2 amps and cpu is getting warm. is that normal?


P.S: <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is getting 0,02 V :D

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
CPU has several power rails.
It can get warm even without VCORE.
If is really bad, then will heat abnormal without its main power.
Resistance (ohm mode) at VCORE should be at least 1 ohm; maybe much more for this board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
Which line is Vcore?

its not getting ahnormal hor, just warm, this why i am
not sure id it is dead cpu or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
"Which line is Vcore?
-----------------------
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>"
We use VCORE as generic term for CPU core power...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
Thanks, 


any suggestion what can i check more to be sure that it is or not CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
Less than 1 ohm at VCORE (ohm scale) is very bad; usually dead CPU.
Lift one side of all CPU coils and check where the low value remains...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message: Thank 2informaticos. Will try and post it tomorrow

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 55733"]Less than 1 ohm at VCORE (ohm scale) is very bad; usually dead CPU.
Lift one side of all CPU coils and check where the low value remains...[/QUOTE]

The short is on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PHX</SIGNAL> ... Can you confirm that it is dead CPU???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no display
threads.message: That is CPU side, so yes (unfortunatelly)...
